course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Computer Communication Networks
course.description: Overview of computer networks: network architecture and switching techniques. Introduction to the Internet, network programming, and layer architecture. Application layer: HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and CDN. Transport layer: TCP and UDP. Network layer: IP routing, NAT, and DHCP. Data link layer and local area networks: MAC protocols, Ethernet, and hubs/bridges/switches.
course.prerequisites: COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P

reviews.author: A random name
reviews.title: Not sure why everyone said don't take this course in fall
reviews.comment_content:
Course Outline
1. Introduction
2. Application Layer
3. Transport Layer
4. Network Layer: The Data Plane
5. Network Layer: The Control Plane
6. Link Layer and LANs
Basically going through all the layers in the network which is not hard to understand. Basically, you can learn all the content by yourself or from online materials (search online). No hard calculations and because the exam is open book, no need to memorize, or remember the page number so you can go to that page quicker. If you studied computer in secondary school, they are similar to this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Just read according to the lecture sides, quite boring. Also, the TA will tell you to search online yourself when you ask them questions about some of the homework questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme
10% - Attendance
20% - Assignments
30% - Midterm
40% - Final

They only took attendance for twice, on the lecture before midterm and the last lecture. That 10% is guaranteed. Assignments are not hard if you have resources. Midterm and final exam questions are mostly very simple.
Midterm: Mean: 68.27, Median: 76
Final Exam: Mean: 75.8, Median: 84

Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Just 4 homework and the content of the homework is almost the same as last fall just with a few changes. No lab this semester, only homework, midterm and final exam. Both midterm and final exam are open notes (only lecture notes and hw with no markings on it), with 1 page a4 paper handwritten note. Before having the midterm and final exam, the professor will give a review on what to study, basically, you attend that lesson, write down what he said and study accordingly then the mark won't be low. Geeksforgeeks will help you a lot on some of the exam questions (for this semester it is helpful, but not sure if it is applicable to all).

reviews.author: clsied
reviews.title: Again, do not take this course in fall
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction
2. Application Layer
3. Transport Layer
4. Network Layer: The Data Plane
5. Network Layer: The Control Plane
6. Link Layer and LANs

Application layer: HTTP, FTP, SMTP, CDN
Transport layer: TCP, UDP
Network layer: IP routing, NAT, DHCP
Data link layer and local area networks: MAC protocols, Ethernet, hubs/bridges/switches
reviews.comment_teaching:
Generally speaking, the professor has carefully explained the content of the course, but the attendance rate was low probably because of his monotonous voice.TAs placed great emphasis on the content of the homework given by the professor, but many parts of what you have written in the homework will not appear in the exam.

For the TAs part, I think there was not much content in tutorials, and many were used to explain the homework. The content of the homework explanation was not very relevant to the content of the homework. In addition, I once sent an e-mail to ask about homework, but TAs did not reply to me at all. When someone asked TAs to postpone the deadline for assignments, the professor responded to us after a week, 12 hours before the deadline. I don’t know if it’s the efficiency issue of TAs.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme

15% - Assignments
15% - Programming Assignments(5% - PA1, 10% - PA2)
30% - Midterm
40% - Final

Both Midterm and Final were conducted online via zoom proctoring. The time for both examinations were tight and the scores for each question were not reasonably distributed. Some details accounted for a lot of test scores. Some knowledge professor emphasized in class only required short answers or even not appear in the test paper. And some questions were out of scope or need some time to think, but the time for the exams was far from enough.

In addition, the rules of the exam were not intuitive. We were required to use mobile phones as zoom lenses and need to be turned on from start to finish and also scanned our answers with mobile phones. But it is almost impossible to accomplish these two things with single mobile phone. In addition, we can only refer to paper notes. Why doesn't the professor require to show our screen? Then it doesn't matter if you check the electronic notes.

Many grades statistics are not shown. You can't judge whether your grades are good or bad. I think if you get the mean in all categories, it will be B-.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is acceptable. Most of it comes from the fact that you have to check homework-related knowledge online. The rest comes from trivial knowledge points, many of which are not just understanding, you must try to memorize them or you won’t have enough time for the exam.

reviews.author: ptrknow
reviews.title: Easy but informative
reviews.comment_content:
Previous course code: ELEC 4120
As stated in the title, easy but informative.

Outline of the content:
1. Network layer I - Address and Routing
2. Transport layer
3. Application layer
4. Network layer II - Routing protocols
5. Data link layer
6. Network Security

The order of topics is different from the usual networking course, since the professor thinks the concept of "address" is fundamental to understanding the upper layers, i.e. transport layer and application layer.

Professor cuts some part in the data link layer in order to make rooms to talk about network security because "the concept of network security is very important to every CSE and ECE students nowadays."

The only downside is the design of the lecture slides. This course certainly deserves better lecture notes design.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is good at explaining things. Please refer to the reviews in ELEC4120 for more details.

In one lecture a student who had just finished his interview asked the professor whether his answer to some interview question was correct, and I remembered the professor interrupted the student and said loudly, "No, your answer is incorrect. You should..." I do think the professor needs not to be that blunt. If I were that student, I probably would be quite upset. Still, the professor's explanation is very clear.

The teaching of the 3 TAs, however, varies a lot. The female TA speaks quite fast, but her explanation is the clearest among the three. Another two male TAs are, at best, mediocre. Still, I found it interesting when one of the male TA always says "this problem is simple" before every explanation, as if that sentence is his catchphrase. At first, I really want to bitch about him, but later, I actually find it very hilarious.
reviews.comment_grading:
7 Homeworks:
TAs will give out hints in tutorial. With the hints, it is not difficult to achieve high (or even full) marks. (This would be another matter if without hints..)

1 Project:
A project that can be finished within an hour

Midterm and Final:
Open book exams. Understand all problems in the homework and pay attention to what is emphasized in the lecture, and you are good to go.

The grade is really decent.
reviews.comment_workload: 7 homeworks might seem quite a lot, but the amount is actually moderate, plus you can bring them into the exam, which greatly reduces the time you need to do revision since you don't need to memorize anything.

reviews.author: operator=
reviews.title: Introductory course to Computer network
reviews.comment_content:
The content are shown in the comment below. The textbook is "Computer Networking: a Top down Approach" which is widely used in computer networking course. And ppt is directly used from the one authors of the textbook made. This course covers the first six chapters. So textbook can provide more detail about the course material.
This course is an introductory course. If you are beginners of computer network, which means you have the following questions in your mind like me before taking this course:
(1) Why does the speed(bandwidth) of wireless network in library is slow in the afternoon when there are increasing students?
(2) I often heard about http, ip, what are they and what is the difference between them?
(3) What do we mean by ip address xx.xx.xx.xx ?
Is ip address dynamic or static?
(4) How do we surf the internet?
(5) What is the difference between host, server, data center?
This course will tell you all the answers.
However, this course does not cover advanced material like: (1) socket programming(only theory, no programming practice)  (2) network security(only talk a few words in the introduction), wireless and mobile network, multimedia networking (in all, none of the last three chapters of the textbook) If you would like to learn more, consider go to COMP course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof mainly reads the note and sometimes add some explanation. It may be boring sometime since this course is more about lots of man-made protocol and theory. But I think prof is nice and you can discuss with him any questions you don't understand in class and his explanation is detailed and satisfactory. For tutorial, some of the classes are used to review the content we learn in the previous week, while the rest is used for giving explanations and hint in homework (very important).
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Attendance + 20% hw + 30% mid + 40% final
The comment below are thorough, I only make several complements.
(1) Some questions of hw are close/same as exercise in the textbook. If you do not find any material online or do not have a friend to discuss, these problems can be difficult.
(2) Midterm and Final only covers those hint discussed in the attendance checking lesson, I know  prof wants us to get high mark in exams this semester.
(3)
Midterm: Upper quartile : 81
Final : Upper quartile : 90  
There is no sd information and since I get highest mark in both midterm and final, so I don't know the approximate grading cutoff but I can guarantee that there is at least 1 A+ (I guess from the comment below he/she also gets A+, at least 2/37 A+ I think the grading will not be bad)
reviews.comment_workload:
This semester only four pieces of written assignment. Each takes around 2-3h. So it is much lighter compared to COMP courses.
This semester prof cuts the socket programming assignment (maybe because it is difficult) and replace that 10% with attendance. But I think socket programming is important in networking(maybe programming is important in networking which is similar to operating system) so I think this assignment can be recovered in the future offerings.

reviews.author: AceOfSpades
reviews.title: A total waste of time.
reviews.comment_content: Overview of computer networks: network architecture and switching techniques. Introduction to the Internet, network programming, and layer architecture. Application layer: HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and CDN. Transport layer: TCP and UDP. Network layer: IP routing, NAT, and DHCP. Data link layer and local area networks: MAC protocols, Ethernet, and hubs/bridges/switches.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This course consists of lecture and tutorial only, both of which don't require attendance.

As for the teaching, it's one of the worst, but what a typical lecturer does in university. You hear the monotone voice from the professor in lectures, and Powerpoint slides being displayed one after another as he reads from the slides.

Like others said, tutorial provides some hints to the questions given in each assignment, but they're not really relevant to the problems you're going to complete. As for the programming assignment, you need a bit of knowledge of Python in order to understand how to make a TCP/UDP server work properly.

The TAs can be a bit more helpful instead of saying "The ability of searching online smartly is crucial for one’s learning. We are all learners in some sense." in the slides. Otherwise, what are the TAs here for? You're only using this as an excuse to shove others away from asking questions.

In the end, all the assignments are a waste of time. You need to search all over the Internet in order to find the solutions for the assignments. I'd have allocated these time to do something meaningful if not for the requirement.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% - Assignments (x3)
15% - Programming Assignments(5% - PA1, 10% - PA2)
30% - Midterm
40% - Final

Midterm and final are both conducted online. You're expected to write your answers, scan them and upload them to Canvas.

It's the annoying type of exam, because the professor isn't really considerate about our situation. According to their rules, we're required to use the smartphones as cameras, and use the very same device to scan the papers. How do you expect us to use the smartphone without leaving the camera on? It's not possible.
reviews.comment_workload: As long as you know how to look for solutions in Google and Stack Overflow as the TAs said, the workload isn't that heavy. Still, it's time-consuming.
